translated: 51. Record of the Axiom Mirror, Scroll 51ğŸ”½
Collected Works of Chan Master Zhizhuo Yan Shou, Abbot of Yongming Temple of the Sun of Wisdom

The names are established based on the characteristics, and the characteristics are revealed based on the names. The names have been extensively discussed. How are the characteristics to be recognized?
Answer:
The expression and indication are called names.
The observable appearance is called characteristics.
The sixth consciousness, the discriminating consciousness, is the name.
Grasping the objects and defiling the mind are the characteristics.
The seventh consciousness, the manifesting consciousness, is the name.
Ignorance perfuming the deluded mind is the characteristic.
The eighth consciousness, the storehouse consciousness, is the name.
The purity of the mind is the characteristic.
The ninth consciousness, the true consciousness, is the name.
The unchanging essence is the characteristic.
These are all the names of the nameless,
The characteristics of the formless.
What is it?
Because the names and characteristics do not go beyond mind and objects.
Therefore, the mind has no self-nature.
It arises based on objects.
The objects have no self-nature.
They exist based on the mind.
This means that the mind has no objects outside of the mind.
There is no mind outside the realm of Zhang.
If they mutually negate each other, both are absent.
Mind and objects are both extinguished.
If they mutually assist each other, both are established.
Mind and objects are distinct.
This is emptiness without nature.
Emptiness without being empty.
Existence without nature.ğŸ”½Existence without being existent.
Existence that is not existent.
Existence manifests the one suchness.
Emptiness that is not empty.
Emptiness accomplishes myriad virtues.
It can be said that myriad existences are destroyed in the empty nature.
Not a single nonexistence remains in the ultimate.
Moreover, the Essentials of Consciousness Only says:
The words arising from the characteristics of one's own mind have two interpretations.
The first says:
They are the characteristics of images.
The second says:
They are the characteristics of what is grasped.
Although they have no real substance,ğŸ”½They appear before the mind.
All explanations of the characteristics of the mind
Should be understood according to this.
The commentary says:
The characteristics of images are:
The myriad dharmas are the images of the mind.
The characteristics of what is grasped are:
The various objects have no substance.
Arising in accordance with grasping.
Arising from one's own mind.
Still serving as the characteristics of the mind.
Question:
What is the name of the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna?
Is it born from its own essence?
Or does it exist through combination?
Answer:
If it is said to be self-born,
this is the delusion of self-birth.
If it is said to be born from another,
this is the delusion of other-nature.
If it is said to be born through combination,
this is the delusion of shared nature.
If it is said to be born apart from self and other,
this is the delusion of no cause.
Now, relying on the worldly truth and skillful means, it is said:
Just as the nature of dharmas combines with ignorance to give rise to all dharmas,
It is like the dreaming mind combining with dreams to see all kinds of things.
This fundamental consciousness
Is established from the gate of arising and ceasing.
It is named through the combination of true and false.
The Awakening of Faith says:
The arising and ceasing aspect of mind
Means that based on the tathÄgatagarbha, the arising and ceasing mind arises.
Non-arising and non-ceasing are united with arising and ceasing.
Not the same and not different.
It is called the Älaya consciousness.
This consciousness has two aspects.
Namely, it can include all dharmas.
It can give rise to all dharmas.
There are also two aspects.
One is the aspect of enlightenment.
The other is the aspect of non-enlightenment.
As for the aspect of enlightenment,
It refers to the ultimate nature of the mind.
Free from all characteristics of deluded thoughts.
Because it is free from all characteristics of deluded thoughts,
It is equal to the realm of space.
There is nothing it does not pervade.
The dharma realm is of one characteristic.
This is precisely the equal dharma body of all tathÄgatas.
Based on this dharma body,
It is said that all tathÄgatas are originally enlightened.
In contrast to initial enlightenment,
It is established as original enlightenment.
However, when there is initial enlightenment,
It is precisely original enlightenment.
There is no separate enlightenment arising.
As for establishing initial enlightenment,ğŸ”½It means that based on original enlightenment there is non-enlightenment.
Based on non-enlightenment, it is said there is initial enlightenment.
Moreover, because the mind's original enlightenment is realized,
it is called ultimate enlightenment.
Because the mind's original non-enlightenment is not realized,
it is not ultimate enlightenment.
As for the meaning of non-enlightenment,
it means that from beginningless time,
one has not truly known the oneness of the true Dharma,
and thus the mind arises with deluded thoughts.
It has no true nature of its own,
but is not apart from original enlightenment.
It is like a person who is lost.
Because he relies on a direction, he becomes lost.
Delusion has no inherent nature of its own,
but is not apart from the direction.
Sentient beings are also like this.
Because they rely on enlightenment,
there is non-enlightenment.
Deluded thoughts give rise to the birth of confusion.
However, that non-enlightenment
has no true nature of its own,
but is not apart from original enlightenment.
It also relies on non-enlightenment
in order to speak of true enlightenment.
Since non-enlightenment does not exist,
true enlightenment is also negated.
An ancient worthy explained:
The mind of non-arising and non-ceasing
unites with arising and ceasing.
As for being neither the same nor different,
the seventh consciousness and defiled dharmas are taken as arising and ceasing.
The pure dharmas of the tathÄgatagarbha are taken as non-arising and non-ceasing.
Because the entire essence of the non-arising and non-ceasing mind moves.
The mind is not apart from the characteristics of arising and ceasing.
Because the characteristics of arising and ceasing are all spiritual understanding.
The characteristics of arising and ceasing are not apart from the mind.
Because of this non-separation,
It is called the combined Älaya consciousness.
Because of the combination,
It is neither one nor different.
If it were one,
There would be no combination.
If it were different,
There would also be no combination.
Because it is neither one nor different,
The combination is possible.
Moreover, the pure mind of the tathÄgatagarbha,
Moves to form arising and ceasing.
Because it is inseparable,
It is therefore called combined.
It does not mean that there is a separate arising and ceasing that comes to combine with the true.
It refers to the mind of arising and ceasing.
Because the arising and ceasing of the mind has no characteristics,
The arising and ceasing of the mind,
Are formed due to ignorance.
The mind of arising and ceasing,
Arises from original enlightenment.
Yet there are no two separate entities.
They are inseparable.
Therefore, it is said that they are combined.
Like the water of the great ocean.
Caused by the wind, the waves move.
The characteristics of water and the characteristics of wind.
Are inseparable.
Birth and non-birth.
If they are one,
When the characteristics of the consciousness of birth and cessation cease,
The essence of the mind and spirit will also cease accordingly.
Falling into the extreme of annihilation.
If they are different,
When the essence of the still mind is moved by the wind of ignorance,
It should not follow conditions.
Then it falls into the extreme of permanence.
Apart from these two extremes,
It is neither the same nor different.
Moreover, the two dharmas of enlightenment and non-enlightenment mentioned above,ğŸ”½Mutually perfuming each other,
Form their defilements and purity.
Since they have no self-nature,
They are entirely one enlightenment.
What is it?
Because of ignorance, non-enlightenment is formed.
Because the meaning of non-enlightenment perfumes the fundamentally enlightened mind,
It gives rise to all defiled dharmas.
Moreover, because the fundamentally enlightened mind perfumes non-enlightenment,
It gives rise to all pure dharmas.
Based on these two meanings,
it gives rise to everything.
Therefore it is said,
Consciousness has two meanings.
It gives rise to all dharmas.
Question:
What is the cause of the Älaya consciousness?ğŸ”½What are its conditions?
What is its essence?
Answer:
The Manifestation of the Mahayana Treatise says,
The Älaya consciousness
is conditioned by the karma and afflictions created and increased in past lives,
and is caused by the perfuming of conceptualization since beginningless time.
It is the essence that arises from all seeds and retribution.
This consciousness is able to grasp and cognize the form faculties,
the bases of the faculties,
and conceptualization.
It is perfumed
at all times,
and the transmigration of birth and death cannot be known.
It is also able to grasp and cognize the external world,
and is associated with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings, etc.
It is exclusively undefiled and indeterminate,
and serves as the supporting cause for the evolving consciousnesses, etc.
The sÅ«tra says,
Covered by ignorance,
Bound by the fetters of craving,
The ignorant person experiences a body with consciousness.
This shows that there is the ripening Älaya consciousness.
Question:
What is the Älaya consciousness?
Its essence is the specific characteristic.
Because it rewards good and evil causes, it is the characteristic of effect.
Because it receives perfuming and holds seeds, it is the characteristic of cause.
Since the eighth consciousness is both cause and effect,
to which of the six causes does it belong?
Among the five effects, which effect is it?
Answer:
Among the six causes, there are four.
In terms of the meaning of holding seeds,
it is the cause of holding seeds.
If the seeds exist simultaneously with the cause,
then it is the co-existent cause.
If it attracts its own kind of seeds in sequence,
then it is the homogeneous cause.
If it is with respect to the simultaneous mental factors, etc.,
then it is the associated cause.
There are no other two causes.
The retributive cause is of good and evil natures.
This consciousness is indeterminate.
If the pervasive cause is defiled,
it refers to views, doubt, ignorance, etc.
This consciousness is not defiled.
Among the five fruits, it has four.
It only excludes the disjunction fruit.
Regarding its own seeds,
it is the homogeneous result.
Regarding attention and other mental factors,
it is the human effort fruit.
Regarding the seventh consciousness,
it is the dominant fruit.
Regarding good and evil causes,
it is the retribution fruit.
Question:
Among the various minds and consciousnesses,
which consciousness is firm and solid,
not swayed by conditions?
Answer:
There is no single dharma in the world that does not arise from conditions.
Dharmas that arise from conditions
are all impermanent.
There is only the fundamental mind,
which does not arise from the prior limit,
does not abide in the middle limit,
and does not cease in the subsequent limit.
It truly is the foundation of myriad existences,
the abode of all Buddhas.ğŸ”½Therefore, it is likened to a mirror,
which can precisely reflect beauty and ugliness.
penetrating deeply into the profound and subtle.
Looking up to it as the fundamental principle,
it is like the great ocean receiving rivers,
or the vast sky containing images.
The Sutra of the Secret Adornment says:
The mind has eight aspects.
Or it may have nine.
Together with ignorance,
it becomes the cause for the world.
The world is all the manifestations of mind and mental factors.
These mind and mental factors,
as well as the various faculties,
arise and cease, flowing and turning,
being transformed by ignorance and other factors.
The fundamental mind
is firm and unmoving.
The worldly causes and conditions
have twelve aspects.
Whether faculties or objects,
they are able to produce and be produced.
They perish in an instant.
From the Brahma world
up to the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
all arise from causes and conditions.
Only the TathÄgata
is free from all causes and conditions.
The inner and outer worlds,
the moving and unmoving dharmas,
are all like vases and so forth,
with the nature of perishing and ceasing.
Another verse says:
You, all Buddha's disciples,
Why do you not see or hear?
The essence of the storehouse consciousness is pure,
The basis of the various bodies.
Sometimes endowed with thirty-two,
Buddha's marks and the marks of a wheel-turning king,
Sometimes taking on various forms,
The world all sees them.
Just like the clear sky and the moon,
Surrounded by the myriad stars,
The various consciousnesses and the Älaya-vijÃ±Äna,
Abide in the body in this way.
Just like the lord of the desire heavens,
Attendants and retinue, playing in the jeweled palace,
The various spirits of the rivers, seas, and so forth,
Freely moving in the water,
The storehouse consciousness abides in the world,
One should know it is also like this.
Just like the myriad things growing from the earth,
The mind manifests many things.
Just like the sun, the heavenly king,
Radiant, riding in the jeweled palace,
Circling around Mount Sumeru,
Flowing everywhere, illuminating the world,
The various heavens and worldly people,
See it and pay homage.
The storehouse consciousness in the Buddha's stage,
Its characteristics are also like this.
Practicing various practices on the ten grounds.
Manifesting the MahÄyÄna Dharma.
Universally bestowing happiness upon sentient beings.
Always praising the TathÄgata.
Abiding in the bodhisattva body.
This is called a bodhisattva.
The Buddha and all bodhisattvas.
Are all called Älaya consciousness.
The Buddha and all his disciples.
Have received or will receive the prediction.
The vast Älaya consciousness.
Attains perfect enlightenment.
Those in the secret and tranquil samÄdhis.
Are in accord with wondrous concentration.
They are able to clearly observe.ğŸ”½The Älaya consciousness.
The Buddha, pratyekabuddhas,
ÅšrÄvakas, and non-Buddhists.
Those who see the principle and are unafraid.
All observe this consciousness.
The various realms of consciousness.
All transform from the mind.
Vessels, clothing, and other things.
Such natures are all nonexistent.
All depend on the Älaya consciousness.
Sentient beings see it in confusion.
Due to various habitual tendencies.
The grasped and grasper continue to turn.
This nature is not like an illusion,
Mirage, and hair-wheel.
Not born, not unborn,
Not empty, not existent.
Like long and short, etc.,
Apart from one, all are nonexistent.
The wise observe illusory phenomena,
All of which are only magical arts.
Never has there been a single thing
That arises together with illusion.
Illusions, mirages, and hair-wheels,
Are seen when combined.
Apart from one, there is no combination.
The past and future are also nonexistent.
Illusory phenomena, hair-wheels, and so forth,
The characteristics of various things,
All of this is the mind's transformation.
Without substance, also without name.
In the world, deluded people,
Their minds are not free.
Falsely speaking of having the ability to create illusions,
Illusions form various things.
The illusionist's bricks, tiles, and so forth,
The various things created,
Various, whether past or future,
These views are all unreal.
Like iron attracted by a magnet,
Moving in the direction it is pointed.
The store consciousness is also like this.
It follows the transformations of discrimination.
In all worlds,
there is no place it does not pervade.
Like the sun and a maá¹‡i jewel,
it is without thought or discrimination.
This consciousness pervades all places.
Seeing it is called saá¹ƒsÄra.
It is neither dead nor born.
Originally, it is not a dharma of saá¹ƒsÄra.
The one in samÄdhi diligently observes.
Saá¹ƒsÄra and nirvÄá¹‡a are like a dream.
At that time, it is the turning of the basis.
It is called liberation.
This is precisely the supreme teaching principle of all buddhas.
It examines and measures all dharmas,
like a scale, like a bright mirror,
also like a great bright lamp,
also like a touchstone for testing gold.
It is far removed from annihilation,
the distinguishing mark of the right path.
The one who cultivates the wondrous samÄdhi
reaches the cause of liberation.
Forever free from all defilements,
the turning of the basis manifests.
Question:
The fundamental consciousness and the various consciousnesses are united,
arising and ceasing together.
When one reaches the stage of transforming the basis,
the consciousnesses of afflictions cease,
only the fundamental consciousness remains.
How is it that discrimination ceases while not ceasing?
The answer is:
The MahÄyÄnasaá¹ƒgraha says:
If the fundamental consciousness and the non-fundamental consciousness
arise and cease together,
it is like water and milk mixed together.ğŸ”½How is it that the fundamental consciousness does not cease,
while the non-fundamental consciousness ceases?
It is like water.
When a goose drinks the milk,
The commentary says:
Although water and milk are mixed together,
when a goose drinks it,
it only drinks the milk,
not the water.
Therefore, although the milk is exhausted,
the water is not exhausted.
The fundamental consciousness and the non-fundamental consciousness are also like this.
Although they are mixed together,
one ceases while the other remains.
Question:
This fundamental consciousness-mind,
since it is called the substance of all dharmas,
it is also said:
to be eternally abiding and unmoving.
Just like the myriad dharmas,ğŸ”½are they within this mind?
Or are they apart from this mind?
If it is this very mind,
and myriad dharmas change and transform,
how can this mind be called eternally abiding?
If it is apart from this mind,
how can it be the essence of all dharmas?
Answer:
Opening and closing follow conditions.
It is neither identical nor different.
Because conditions come together, they are combined.ğŸ”½Because conditions disperse, they open.
Opening and closing are merely conditions.
Coiling and unfolding have no substance.
Conditions only open and close.
Conditions are also originally empty.
This and that have no knowledge.
The able and the object are both quiescent.
A verse from the Sutra of the Secret Adornment says:
It is like gold, stone, and so forth,
which originally have no water-like characteristics.
When combined with fire,
if water flows and moves,
the storehouse consciousness is also like this.
The essence is not a dharma of flowing and turning.
The various consciousnesses are mutually corresponding,
and with dharmas, they flow and turn together.
Like iron due to a lodestone,
it revolves and moves.
Both are without thought,
appearing as if there is thought and awareness.
The Älaya and the seven consciousnesses,
One should know, are also like this.
Bound by the rope of habits,
Without a person, yet as if there is.
Universally pervading the bodies of sentient beings,
Circling through the various destinies.
Like iron and a magnet,
They revolve without mutual knowledge.
Question:
How many kinds does the eighth store consciousness have?
Answer:
The Commentary on the MahÄyÄna Treatise says:
The Älaya consciousness
Has ten kinds in total.
Why is this?
Because it is explained separately in the sÅ«tras.
First,
It is called the great sovereign Älaya consciousness.
This refers to the general characteristic of the great consciousness.
The meaning is as explained above.
Second,
It is called fundamental ignorance.
It is established separately as the Älaya consciousness.
Therefore, the ten kinds of conceptualization,
The sÅ«tras say like this:
The consciousness of King Ká¹£emaá¹…kara,
Is simply a deluded dharma.
They are unable to understand the essence of the one dharma realm.
All defiled dharmas.
The Älaya consciousness.
Serves as their fundamental basis.
They are produced and grow.
Without a time of cessation.
If there were no Älaya consciousness.
The retinue of the black category.
Would forever have no basis.
And would be unable to be produced and grow.
This Älaya consciousness.
To which of the ten categories of dharmas does it belong?
In this treatise.
It is explained as follows.
As for the meaning of non-enlightenment.
It means not truly understanding the one suchness of the dharma realm.
The unenlightened mind arises and there is thought.
And so on, as explained in detail.
Third,
It is called the pure fundamental enlightenment Älaya consciousness.
It refers to the naturally fundamental wisdom.
It is separately established as the Älaya.
Therefore, in the Fundamental Enlightenment Scripture.
It is explained as follows.
The self-nature pure buddha Älaya consciousness.
Is endowed with the pure and perfect merits.
It is constant, eternal, and definite.
It has no characteristic of receiving perfuming.
It has no characteristic of change.
The essence of wisdom is unmoving.
It is fully endowed with the pure aspects.
Therefore, it is called the sole pure consciousness.
Therefore, this Älaya consciousness,
to which discrimination should it be attributed?
In the fundamental treatise,
it is explained as follows:
Furthermore, the essence and characteristics of enlightenment
have four great meanings.
It is equal to space.
It is like a pure mirror.
And so on, it is explained in detail.
Fourth,
it is called the defiled and pure fundamentally pure Älaya consciousness.
It refers to the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« wisdom that does not guard its own nature.
It is separately established as the Älaya consciousness.
Therefore, in the fundamental causes and conditions for the arising of the sÅ«tra,
it is explained as follows:
At that time, the youth Guangyan
immediately said to the Buddha,
Venerable One,
for what reason
in the assembly of the unprecedented gathering that is difficult to enter,
did you say this?
The dhÄraá¹‡Ä« wisdom that arises in accordance with other conditions
Is called the consciousness of the king of Laá¹…kÄ.
What is meant by the king of Laá¹…kÄ?
Using it as a metaphor,
It shows the dhÄraá¹‡Ä« wisdom of dependent origination.
Then the Venerable One said to Guangyan,
Young man,
This king of Laá¹…kÄ
Always resides on Mount Malaya in the great ocean,
Leading an assembly of 160,000 ghosts and spirits,
As his retinue.
Such are the members of the retinue,
Riding in a palace of flowers,
Wandering through various lands,
All relying on the king of Laá¹…kÄ,
Only then can they travel.
The so-called assembly of ghosts and spirits,
Say such words:
We, the assembly of spirits,
Have no majestic virtue,
Have no strength,
In all our undertakings,
We have no ability.
As befits the great king,
Among our assembly,
Grant us capable power.
The king of Laá¹…kÄ,
Then, at that time,
And bestows supreme power.
Not separating from each other.
And turning together.
It means, O King of Laá¹…kÄ,
Although not having a divided body,
Yet it can pervade the multitudes of spirits,
Each causing them to obtain the full measure of the whole body.ğŸ”½At all times,
In all places,
Turning together without separation.
The wisdom that does not guard its own nature,
Is also like this.
It can receive all immeasurable and boundless defiled dharmas of afflictions,
The perfuming of the multitudes of ghosts and spirits,
Not separating from each other,
And turning together.
For this reason,
I make such statements in the difficult entry.
The wisdom of following and turning,
Is called the consciousness of King Laá¹…kÄ.
Therefore, this Älaya consciousness,
To which discrimination should it be included?
In the fundamental treatise,
It is said like this:
The intrinsically pure mind,
Is moved by the wind of ignorance.
The mind and ignorance,
Both have no form or characteristics.
are not separate from each other.
And so on, as extensively explained.
Fifth,
it is called the characteristic of karma, the karma-consciousness Älaya-vijÃ±Äna.
It refers to the fundamental characteristic of karma,
and the karma-consciousness,
which are separately established as the Älaya.
Therefore, in the SÅ«tra of Innate Wisdom,
it is said like this:
The Älaya-vijÃ±Äna,ğŸ”½has no ability to cognize,
and nothing to cognize.
It cannot be analyzed,
and cannot be distinguished.
It is only called the key-word (keyÅ«ra) because of its subtle, hidden, and flowing meaning.
Therefore, this Älaya-vijÃ±Äna,
to which category does it belong?
In the fundamental treatise,
it is said like this:
Furthermore, based on non-awakening,
three kinds of characteristics arise.
They are associated with and inseparable from that non-awakening.
What are the three?
First, the characteristic of the activity of ignorance.
Because it is based on non-awakening, the mind moves.
This is called activity.
If there is awareness, there is no movement.
If there is movement, there is suffering.
Because the effect does not depart from the cause.
Sixth,
It is called the evolving aspect, the evolving consciousness, the Älaya consciousness.
It is said to be the aspect of seeing the objects,
And together with the evolving consciousness,
It is separately established as the Älaya.
Therefore, the MahÄ-apramÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra says:
The Älaya consciousness,
Has the seen part of seeing evolving,
And the seen part of seeing arising without seeing.
Therefore, this Älaya consciousness,
To which discrimination should it be included?
In the root text, it is said:
Second, the aspect of seeing,
Because it is able to see based on movement,
If there is no movement, there is no seeing.
Seventh,
It is called the manifesting aspect consciousness, the Älaya consciousness.
It is said to be the aspect of the objects,
And together with the manifesting consciousness,
It is separately established as the Älaya.
Therefore, the SÅ«tra of Ultimate Reality says:
Distinct, distinct.
The stage of the ground of present realization.
The characteristics of characteristics.
The stage of complete practice.
Therefore, it is called the Älaya consciousness.
Furthermore, this Älaya consciousness.
Is truly the retribution of indeterminate dharmas.
Because of its pure characteristics.
Or it is called accomplishment.
Therefore, this Älaya consciousness.
To which category does it belong?
In the fundamental treatise.
It is said like this.
Third, the characteristic of objects.
Because it relies on the ability to see.
Objects falsely appear.
Apart from seeing, there are no objects.
The eighth.
Is called the principle of the true nature of suchness of the Älaya consciousness.
That is to say, the pure suchness realized by right wisdom.
It is separately established as the Älaya consciousness.
Therefore, the sÅ«tra on the same essence of all dharmas says like this.
There is consciousness.
It is consciousness.
It is not included in the consciousnesses.ğŸ”½That is to say, it is the suchness of the Älaya consciousness.
Therefore, this Älaya consciousness.
What is the definitive classification?
It is said to be the pure prajÃ±Ä that takes the true nature as its object, and is therefore included in true suchness.
Ninth,
It is called the pure, newly enlightened Älaya-vijÃ±Äna.
It refers to the innate pure and bright newly enlightened prajÃ±Ä.
It is separately established as the Älaya.
Therefore, when the fruit is perfectly complete,
The sÅ«tras say:
The Buddha told the Bodhi Tree King:
The naturally newly enlightened Älaya-vijÃ±Äna,
Should always be inseparable from the pure original enlightenment.
The pure original enlightenment,
Should always be inseparable from the newly enlightened pure consciousness.ğŸ”½Following this, there is that.
Following that, there is this.
Either not of the same kind,
Or not of different kinds.
This Älaya-vijÃ±Äna,
What is the definitive classification?
In the fundamental treatise,
It is said:
As for the meaning of original enlightenment,ğŸ”½In contrast to newly enlightened,
It is the same as original enlightenment.
Tenth,
It is called the defiled and pure beginningless consciousness.
It is called the wisdom of beginningless enlightenment that accords with conditions.
It is separately established as the Älaya.
Therefore, the fruition is perfect and complete.
The sutra says:
Furthermore, O King of Trees,
Just as the pure consciousness of beginningless enlightenment
And one's own original enlightenment
Are said to be the defiled and pure beginningless consciousness,
Not guarding one's own nature,
The originally enlightened dependent arising,
Is also like this.
Therefore, this Älaya consciousness
Should be categorized as what?
In the fundamental treatise,
It is said like this:
As for the meaning of beginningless enlightenment,ğŸ”½Based on original enlightenment, there is non-enlightenment.
Based on non-enlightenment, there is beginningless enlightenment.
Moreover, because one awakens to the source of the enlightened mind,
It is called ultimate enlightenment.
Because one does not awaken to the source of the mind,
It is not ultimate enlightenment.
Up to here, the gate of the separate characteristics of the dissected Älaya consciousness has been explained.
Next, the gate of the perfect and complete Älaya consciousness that subsumes all phenomena will be explained.
This consciousness has two kinds of meanings.ğŸ”½It is able to include all dharmas.
It is able to give rise to all dharmas.
The first is the meaning of enlightenment.
The second is the meaning of non-enlightenment.
It comprehensively reveals the superior and perfect characteristics of the great consciousness.
What is the meaning of this?
It is said that because it is endowed with two kinds of perfection.
The first is the perfection of merits.
The second is the perfection of faults.
As for the perfection of merits,

But because of the delusion of the understanding of the One True [Nature],
One makes the second contemplation.
Initially, the mind that is able to illuminate through awakened understanding,
Gives rise to the characteristics of internal and external dust and afflictions.
Within the one perfect and still [mind],
The faculties and sense objects are separated out.
The internal four great elements are gathered to form the body,
And the external four great elements are divided to form the environment.
Internally, the defilements are the discriminating consciousnesses,
And externally, the dust is formed by conceptual appearances.
Without thought, the realm penetrates the one suchness,
But with conceptualization, the true nature becomes myriad distinctions.
If one is able to merge the mind with the Dharma realm,
And the environment opens up to the true emptiness,
The illusory veils will completely disappear,
And the one path of illumination will manifest.
This can be called tearing apart the dense web of delusion,
And pulling out the heavy bolt on the door of awakening.
When the confusion and dreams awaken, the great enlightenment is always bright.
